sourceString: Preliminary Estimates of the Prevalence of Selected Underlying Health Conditions Among Patients with Coronavirus Disease 2019 — United States, February 12–March 28, 2020
targetString: Somwa Badiyarambe Ngǝwutǝ Kǝndawa Nǝlewabe Kartǝna ma Dawu Am nǝm Dondi coronavirusbe tiyinzan Mbejiye 2019 ___ lardǝ United Statesbe, February 12--March 28, 2020

sourceString: On March 11, 2020, the World Health Organization declared Coronavirus Disease 2019 (COVID-19) a pandemic.
targetString: March 11, 2020na, Karapka Nǝlewabe Dunyabeye kwasa koronabairosbe (COVID-19) dǝ'a wawa dunya samma so zuwuna lan bowono.

sourceString: As of March 28, 2020, a total of 571,678 confirmed COVID-19 cases and 26,494 deaths have been reported worldwide.
targetString: Kǝntage Marchye kawunzǝ 28nna, saa 2020 lan, lamarra COVID-19be 571,678 tawattǝgǝ na kuru kǝrmu kam 26,494ye dunya samma son rifot tuwandǝna.

sourceString: Reports from China and Italy suggest that risk factors for severe disease include older age and the presence of at least one of several underlying health conditions.
targetString: Rifotwa China-a Italy-a lan tuwandǝnaye fǝlejin awowa fujiwo nǝm dondi kǝrau sawudin dǝ sandima nǝm kura au ngǝli letǝ-a kuru nǝm dondi laa buro man mbeji.

sourceString: U.S. older adults, including those aged ≥65 years and particularly those aged ≥85 years, also appear to be at higher risk for severe COVID-19–associated outcomes; however, data describing underlying health conditions among U.S. COVID-19 patients have not yet been reported.
targetString: U.S lan ammurawa ngǝlinza lezǝna, am ngǝlinza ≥65 kuru taganasma ro ammurawa ngǝlinza ≥85, sandima zauro suro fujiwo nǝm dondi COVID-19'a leyata sandiya sǝtayin kasharu; sapsapno bayanbe do kǝndawa nǝlewabe am U.S lan COVID-19ye sǝtana fǝlejin dǝ kuwayaye rifotnzǝ tǝdǝnyi.

sourceString: As of March 28, 2020, U.S. states and territories have reported 122,653 U.S. COVID-19 cases to CDC, including 7,162 (5.8%) for whom data on underlying health conditions and other known risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections were reported.
targetString: Kǝntagǝ Marisbe kaunzǝ 28nna saa 2020, lardǝ U.S.be-a dǝrinǝmkǝllenzǝ-aye kessa COVID-19ye sandi 122,653 CDC ro rifot sadǝna, suro dǝn mbeji kessa 7,162 (ci 5.8%) sandi do sapsapno bayanbe kǝla kǝndawa nǝlewabe caman mbeji-a kuru awowa fujiwo suwudin gade so sandi do kwasawa yintǝbe zau sawudin ma rifot tǝdǝna.

sourceString: Among these 7,162 cases, 2,692 (37.6%) patients had one or more underlying health condition or risk factor, and 4,470 (62.4%) had none of these conditions reported.
targetString: Dau lamarra au kessa 7,162 ye dǝn, am dondi 2,692 (37.6%) yedei dǝ nǝm dondi fal au falla kozǝna buroman sha zǝkcin ma mbeji au awo fujiwo suwudin ma, kuru kam 4,470 (62.4%) dǝ affima sandiya buron zǝkcin ma ba.

sourceString: The percentage of COVID-19 patients with at least one underlying health condition or risk factor was higher among those requiring intensive care unit (ICU) admission (358 of 457, 78%) and those requiring hospitalization without ICU admission (732 of 1,037, 71%) than that among those who were not hospitalized (1,388 of 5,143, 27%).
targetString: Adadu am COVID-19ye sǝtana kuru tiyinzan nǝm dondi gananzǝyaye fal yedei buroman mbeji au awo fujiwo suwudin mbeji ma dǝ sandi ma zauro ngǝwu wo dawu am sandiya ICUro ikko mǝradǝzanabe lan (358 suro 457, 78%) kuru sandi do litarin rota ngai mǝradǝza ICUro ikko ba dǝ (732 suro 1,037yen, 71%), kuru am sandiya litarin rotǝnyi (1,388 suro 5143, 27%).

sourceString: The most commonly reported conditions were diabetes mellitus, chronic lung disease, and cardiovascular disease.
targetString: Nǝm dondi do zauro ngǝwu ro rifotnza tuwandin dǝ sandi ma kwasa shiwurbe-a, kwasa fufube zauro zauma-a, kuru kwasa nasha karǝgǝ-a kaso buye-a leyata ma.

sourceString: These preliminary findings suggest that in the United States, persons with underlying health conditions or other recognized risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections appear to be at a higher risk for severe disease from COVID-19 than are persons without these conditions.
targetString: Awowa tuwandǝna badiyarambe dǝye fǝlezǝna lardǝ United Statesye dǝn, am do nǝm dondi laa caman sandiya zǝkcin au awo laa fujiwo suwudin gade noatama do kwasa yintǝbe kǝrau ro sǝdin ma so dǝ sandima zauro suro fujiwo nǝm dondi COVID-19be zzauma sandiya sǝtayin yen kasharu, am tiyinzan awowa anyi ba ro wungǝmmiya.

sourceString: Data from laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 cases reported to CDC from 50 states, four U.S. territories and affiliated islands, the District of Columbia, and New York City with February 12–March 28, 2020 onset dates were analyzed.
targetString: Sapsawi bayanbe lamarra COVID-19be lab lan tawattǝgǝna do CDC ro rifotnza taadvna suro kǝriyewa 50be-a, cidiwa 4 cidiya U. Syen dasaana-a kuru cidiya njiye dǝrizǝ kǝlzǝna do U.S ro tǝngataana'a, kuru na shiro 'District of Columbia' sayin daa, bǝrni New Yorkbe-a, kǝntagǝ Februarybe kau 12 - kǝntagǝ Marchbe kau 28, saa 2020 sandi ma yimma baditǝbe ro gǝnatǝna dǝ samma kulastǝ na.

sourceString: Cases among persons repatriated to the United States from Wuhan, China, and the Diamond Princess cruise ship were excluded.
targetString: Kessa dawu am do sandiya United States ro Wuhan-a, China-a, kuru maara njibe kǝji fantǝbe shiro Diamond Princess sayin dǝ'a lan kalaktǝnayen tuwandǝna so dǝ dawun ba.

sourceString: For cases with missing onset dates, date of onset was estimated by subtracting 4 days (median interval from symptom onset to specimen collection date among cases with known dates in these data) from the earliest specimen collection.
targetString: Lamarra do yim kau kǝntagǝye baditǝnzabe ba ma dǝ yim badtǝnzabe dǝ kau diyeu yim buro salakyen "specimen tǝmona" lan tulo men komtin.

sourceString: Public health departments reported cases to CDC using a standardized case report form that captures information (yes, no, or unknown) on the following conditions and potential risk factors: chronic lung disease (inclusive of asthma, chronic obstructive pulmonary disease [COPD], and emphysema); diabetes mellitus; cardiovascular disease; chronic renal disease; chronic liver disease; immunocompromised condition; neurologic disorder, neurodevelopmental, or intellectual disability; pregnancy; current smoking status; former smoking status; or other chronic disease.
targetString: Fellawa Nǝlewa Jamabeye CDC ro rifot lamarra au kessaye cina, fom rifot kesbeye ngalwo do bayanna gojin ma (aa'a, a'aa, au notǝnyi) kǝla kǝndawa anyibe-a kuru awowa fujiwo suwudin ma so-ayen: kwasa fufube zauro zau ma (suro dǝn asǝma-a, 'chronic obstructive pulmonary disease-a[COPD), kuru 'emphysema'-a mbeji); kwasa shiwurbe; kwasa karǝgǝbe-a letǝ buye-a; kwasa kǝtǝlilam au collorambe zauma; kwasa kǝmattǝn be zauro zau ma; kǝnda do duno kwasa luwalatǝbe tiyibe fulujin ma; kwasa caube. kwasa fuwutǝ hangalbe; suro; kǝrma ro tafa kǝnza, tafa kǝnza buroye; au kwasawa zau gade so.

sourceString: Data reported to CDC are preliminary and can be updated by health departments over time; critical data elements might be missing at the time of initial report; thus, this analysis is descriptive, and no statistical comparisons could be made.
targetString: Sapsawi bayanbe CDC ro rifotnzǝ sadǝna dǝ badiyarambe kuru fellawa nǝlewabeye soye raksa bayan gade sasarayin suro kun balinyen; awowa laa sapsawi bayanbe muhimmi au zauro faida'a loktu nuro salak rifot dǝ sadǝna dǝn waniye ba ro waljin; daji adǝye sǝkkǝ, kulashi adǝ yikkuwaltobe, kuru rataltǝgǝ somye mowonzǝ tǝdǝnyi.

sourceString: The percentages of patients of all ages with underlying health conditions who were not hospitalized, hospitalized without ICU admission, and hospitalized with ICU admission were calculated.
targetString: Adadu am dondi samma soye (kura ba gana ba) do buroman nǝm dondi laa tiyinzan mbeji amma sandiya litarin rozanyibe-a, litarin rozana amma ICU (na kam zauro dondi ro cistǝgǝ kambo diobe) tǝkkǝnyi-a, kuru litarin rozana kuru ICU ro tǝkkǝna-a be dǝ komtǝna.

sourceString: Percentages of hospitalizations with and without ICU admission were estimated for persons aged ≥19 years with and without underlying health conditions.
targetString: Adadu litarin rotǝ ICU ro ikko mbeji-a ba-a ye dǝ am saa ≥19 (meu laarin samin) ro komgatǝ, nǝm dondi laa buroman mbeji-a ba-a son.

sourceString: This part of the analysis was limited to persons aged ≥19 years because of the small sample size of cases in children with reported underlying health conditions (N = 32).
targetString: Kulashi dǝye nashanzǝ adǝ am saa ≥19 bas ro tǝdin dalil nǝm gana samfǝrye kessa ndulibe do buro man nǝm dondi laa sandiya zǝkcinye rifot tǝdǝna ma (N=32).

sourceString: To account for missing data among these preliminary reports, ranges were estimated with a lower bound including cases with both known and unknown status for hospitalization with and without ICU admission as the denominator and an upper bound using only cases with known outcome status as the denominator.
targetString: Sapsawi bayanbe suro rifot badiyarambeye fattǝgǝna ma ye na dǝ kǝptǝgǝ ro, som dǝ tǝdǝna kessa do litarin rotǝna ro notǝna-a notǝnyi-a do ICU ro tǝkkǝna-a tǝkkǝnyi-a ro, kuru kessa tamoram noata'a ye faidatǝna.

sourceString: Because of small sample size and missing data on underlying health conditions among COVID-19 patients who died, case-fatality rates for persons with and without underlying conditions were not estimated.
targetString: Dalil nǝm gana samfǝrbe-a kuru fattǝgǝ sapsawi bayanbeye kǝla kǝnda nǝm dondi caman mbejiye dawu am COVId-19ye cezǝnaye sǝkkǝ, nǝm ngǝwu kǝrmube am nǝm dondi laa buroman sandiya zǝkcin mbeji-a ba-aye dǝ komtǝnyi.

sourceString: As of March 28, 2020, a total of 122,653 laboratory-confirmed COVID-19 cases (Figure) and 2,112 deaths were reported to CDC.
targetString: Kǝntagǝ Marchye kaunzǝ 28, saa 2020 lan, kessa COVID-19ye lab lan tawattǝgǝna sandi 122,653 kuru kǝrmu 2,112ye rifot CDC ro sadǝna.

sourceString: Case report forms were submitted to CDC for 74,439 (60.7%) cases.
targetString: Fomwa kes rifot diobe CDC ro sandi 74,439 (60.7%) taadǝna.

sourceString: Data on presence or absence of underlying health conditions and other recognized risk factors for severe outcomes from respiratory infections (i.e., smoking and pregnancy) were available for 7,162 (5.8%) patients (Table 1).
targetString: Sapsawi bayanbe kǝla nǝm mbeji au nǝm ba nǝm dondi buro man mbejibe-a kuru awowa fujiwo suwudin noata ma kwasa yintǝbe zau suwuddin (tafa kǝnza-a nǝm de gǝnyi-a) be sandi am dondi 7,162 (ci 5.8%) mbeji (Tewur 1)

sourceString: Approximately one third of these patients (2,692, 37.6%), had at least one underlying condition or risk factor.
targetString: Alama suro ci yakkǝyen ci fal am dondibe dǝ (2,692, 37.6%), gananzǝ yaye nǝm dondi buro man sandiya zǝkcin fal yaye tiyinzan mbeji au awo laa fujiwo suwudin ma mbeji.

sourceString: Diabetes mellitus (784, 10.9%), chronic lung disease (656, 9.2%), and cardiovascular disease (647, 9.0%) were the most frequently reported conditions among all cases.
targetString: Kwasa shiwurye (784, ci 10.9%), kwasa fufube zau ma (656, ci 9.2%), kuru kwasa karǝgǝbe-a letǝ buye-a (647, ci 9.0%) sandima nǝm dondiwa do ngǝwu so ro rifotnza tǝdin wo suro kessa samma soyen.

sourceString: Among 457 ICU admissions and 1,037 non-ICU hospitalizations, 358 (78%) and 732 (71%), respectively occurred among persons with one or more reported underlying health condition.
targetString: Dawu am ICU lan litarin rotǝna sandi 457 kuru litarin rotǝna ICU ro tǝkkǝnyi sandi 1,037nna, 358 (ci 78%) -a kuru 732 (ci 71%) wakazǝ dawu am do nǝm dondi fal au falla kozǝna do buroman tiyinzan mbeji ma soyen.

sourceString: In contrast, 1,388 of 5,143 (27%) COVID-19 patients who were not hospitalized were reported to have at least one underlying health condition.
targetString: Adǝ ro gadezǝna, suro am 5,143 COVID 19ye sǝtana do sandiya litarin rotǝnyiye lan, 1,388 (ci 27%) dǝ tiyinzan gananzǝ yaye nǝm dondi laa buroman sandiya zǝkcin ma mbeji.

sourceString: Among patients aged ≥19 years, the percentage of non-ICU hospitalizations was higher among those with underlying health conditions (27.3%–29.8%) than among those without underlying health conditions (7.2%–7.8%); the percentage of cases that resulted in an ICU admission was also higher for those with underlying health conditions (13.3%–14.5%) than those without these conditions (2.2%–2.4%) (Table 2).
targetString: Dawu am dondi saa ≥19 saminnayen, adadu litarin rotǝ ICU ro ikko ba dǝ dawu am nǝm dondi laa buroman sandiya zǝkcinna'aye (27.3% - 29.8%) dǝ nǝm ngǝwun am nǝm dondi laa sandiya zǝkcin (7.2% - 7.8%) ma ba ma kozǝna; adadu kessa ICU ro ikko suwudǝna be dǝ shiye dawu am nǝm dondi laa sandiya buroman zǝkcin ma dǝ (13.3% - 14.5%) nǝm ngǝwun am nǝm dondi laa sandiya zǝkcin ma ba (2.2% - 2.4%) kozǝna.

sourceString: Small numbers of COVID-19 patients aged < 19 years were reported to be hospitalized (48) or admitted to an ICU (eight).
targetString: Am COVID-19 ye sǝtana gana laa saanza < 19 cidiyan litarin rotǝnabe rifot tuwandǝna (48) suro ICU ro tǝkkǝna (8).

sourceString: In contrast, 335 patients aged < 19 years were not hospitalized and 1,342 had missing data on hospitalization.
targetString: Adǝ ro gadezǝna, am dondi sandi 335 saa < 19 sandiya litarin rotǝnyi kuru am 1,342 sapsawi bayanbe kǝla sandiya litarin rotabe dǝ fattǝgǝna.

sourceString: Among all COVID-19 patients with complete information on underlying conditions or risk factors, 184 deaths occurred (all among patients aged ≥19 years); 173 deaths (94%) were reported among patients with at least one underlying condition.
targetString: Dawu am COVID-19ye sǝtana samma soyen sandi do bayan kaamil kǝla nǝm dondi caman sandiya zǝkcin mbejiya au awowa fujiwo'a laa mbeji ma yen, kǝrmu 184 wakazǝ (samma so dawu am saa ≥19 be lan); kǝrmu 173 (94%) ye rifot taadǝna dawu am dondi do caman nǝm dondi laa sandiya zǝkcin ma mbeji yen.

sourceString: Among 122,653 U.S. COVID-19 cases reported to CDC as of March 28, 2020, 7,162 (5.8%) patients had data available pertaining to underlying health conditions or potential risk factors; among these patients, higher percentages of patients with underlying conditions were admitted to the hospital and to an ICU than patients without reported underlying conditions.
targetString: Dawu kessa COVID-19be 122,653 CDC ro rifotnzǝ taadǝna yim kǝntagǝ Marchbe kau 28, saa 2020 ye dǝn, am dondi 7,162 (ci 5.8%) sapsawi bayanbe kǝla nǝm dondinza do buroman sandiya zǝkcinben mbeji au awo laa fujiwoo'a sandiya wujin mbeji maye mbeji; dawu am dondi anyiben, adadu am nǝm dondi laa caman sandiya zǝkcin mbeji'aye ngǝwu litarin rozana kuru ICUye ro sakkǝna, am ngai maa ngǝwun kozana.

sourceString: These results are consistent with findings from China and Italy, which suggest that patients with underlying health conditions and risk factors, including, but not limited to, diabetes mellitus, hypertension, COPD, coronary artery disease, cerebrovascular disease, chronic renal disease, and smoking, might be at higher risk for severe disease or death from COVID-19.
targetString: Tamoramwa anyi awowa China-a Italy-a lan tuwandǝna-a kalkalzǝna, adǝbe fǝlejin am dondi do nǝm dondi laa buroman sandiya zǝkcin-a kuru awo laa kǝnǝnganza ro fujiwo suwudin-a, suro dǝn mbeji amma anyi lan dajimba, kwasa shiwurbe-a, bawo buye shiro 'hypertension' gulzayin dǝ-a, COPD-a, kwasa caube-a, 'cerebrovascular disease'-a, kwasa nasha collobe zauro zau-a, kuru tafa kǝnza-a, sandi ma waniye suro fujiwo zauro donditǝbeyen au kǝrmuyen wo dalil COVID-19ben.

sourceString: This analysis was limited by small numbers and missing data because of the burden placed on reporting health departments with rapidly rising case counts, and these findings might change as additional data become available.
targetString: Kulashi adǝ adadu gana-a kuru sapsawi bayanbe fattǝgǝ-a ye sha naskanzǝna dalil kǝrawu do fellawa rifot yadoma so ro gǝnatǝgǝnayen kessa zauro ngǝwu zayin ye sǝkkǝ, kuru kulashiwa anyi waniye faltin sa sapsawi bayanbe gade tuwandiya.

sourceString: It is not yet known whether the severity or level of control of underlying health conditions affects the risk for severe disease associated with COVID-19.
targetString: Kǝmaa dǝ ro notǝnyi nǝm zau au daraja kaltǝgǝ nǝm dondi buroman mbejiye fujiwo do kwasa zau COVID-19'a leyatabe dǝ lejin la lejimba ro.

sourceString: Many of these underlying health conditions are common in the United States: based on self-reported 2018 data, the prevalence of diagnosed diabetes among U.S. adults was 10.1%, and the U.S. age-adjusted prevalence of all types of heart disease (excluding hypertension without other heart disease) was 10.6% in 2017.
targetString: Nǝm dondi buroman mbeji anyi ngǝwunza so United States lan zauro ngǝwu: sapsawi bayanbe saa 2018be lan kǝlanza la ro rifot sadǝna ro wuntǝiyya, nǝm ngǝwu kwasa shiwurbe dawu ammurawa U.S be dǝ ci 10.1% ma sǝtǝna, kuru nǝm ngǝwu kwasa karǝgǝ'a leyata be dǝ (hypertension dawun ba ro) ci 10.6% suro saa 2017yen.

sourceString: The age-adjusted prevalence of COPD among U.S. adults is 5.9%, and in 2018, the U.S. estimated prevalence of current asthma among persons of all ages was 7.9%.
targetString: Nǝm ngǝwu COPDbe dawu ammurawa U.S.be dǝ ci 5.9%, kuru saa 2018 be lan, U.S.ye nǝm ngǝwu asǝmabe dawu amma yen kura ba gana baye dǝ ci 7.9% ro somgono.

sourceString: CDC continues to develop and update resources for persons with underlying health conditions to reduce the risk of acquiring COVID-19.
targetString: CDCdǝ sambiso ro am nǝm dondi laa buroman sandiya zǝkcin nankaro razuwwa sǝtandinye ngalwozǝyinye fujiwo COVID-19 gotǝbe fulutǝ nankaro.

sourceString: The estimated higher prevalence of these conditions among those in this early group of U.S. COVID-19 patients and the potentially higher risk for more severe disease from COVID-19 associated with the presence of underlying conditions highlight the importance of COVID-19 prevention in persons with underlying conditions.
targetString: Nǝm ngǝwu kǝndawa nǝlewabe somtǝna anyi dawu am U.S.ye COVID-19ye sǝtanabe dǝ-a kuru fujiwo zauro kura nǝm dondi zauro zau COVID-19'a leyata dǝ nǝm mbeji kǝndawa nǝlewabe buroman mbeji'a leyataye fǝlezǝna nǝm ngalwo COVID-19 suro am nǝm dondi laa buroman sandiya zǝkcinyen kaltǝgǝbe.

sourceString: The findings in this report are subject to at least six limitations.
targetString: Awowa rifot allan tuwandǝna dǝ dalil gananzǝ yaye awowa arakkǝ anyi sandiro ta'asa saudinyen waano.

sourceString: First, these data are preliminary, and the analysis was limited by missing data related to the health department reporting burden associated with rapidly rising case counts and delays in completion of information requiring medical chart review; these findings might change as additional data become available.
targetString: Kǝn tilo mi dǝ, sapsawi bayanbe anyi badiyarambe, kuru kulashi dǝ'a fattǝgǝ sapsawi bayanbeye naskanzǝna dalil rifot yado fella nǝlewabe do ngǝwutǝ kessabe ye sǝkkǝ zauro ngvnvwu-a ro walzǝna, kuru loktu banna nasha 'medical chart review' bayan mǝradǝzvna tamotǝbe-a; awowa tuwandǝna anyi waniye faltin bayan gade tuwandinna son.

sourceString: Information on underlying conditions was only available for 7,162 (5.8%) of 122,653 cases reported to CDC.
targetString: Bayan kǝla kǝndawa nǝlewabe buroman mbejiye dǝ am 7,162 (5.8%) basye mbeji wo suro kessa 122,653 ye CDC ro rifot tǝdǝnayen.

sourceString: It cannot be assumed that those with missing information are similar to those with data on either hospitalizations or underlying health conditions.
targetString: Mowonzǝ amm do bayannanza fattǝgǝna dǝ am sapsawi bayanzabe mbeji'a tilo ro gotimba wo nasha litarin rotaben au kǝnda nǝlewabe buroman mbejiyen.

sourceString: Second, these data are subject to bias in outcome ascertainment because of short follow-up time.
targetString: Kǝn indi mi, sapsawiya bayanbe anyi mowonzǝ waniye kalkal gǝnyi ro waljin dalil loktu ngǝlaro tawattǝgǝye baa yen.

sourceString: Some outcomes might be underestimated, and long-term outcomes cannot be assessed in this analysis.
targetString: Tamoramwa au awowa tuwandǝna laa dǝ affima gǝnyi ro gotin, kuru awowa loktu kuruwu lan tuwandǝna dǝ mowonzǝ kulashi adǝ lan kulastimba.

sourceString: Third, because of the limited availability of testing in many jurisdictions during this period, this analysis is likely biased toward more severe cases, and findings might change as testing becomes more widespread.
targetString: Kǝn yakkǝ mi, loktu allan ganatǝ test au jarabtǝye na'a kada lanye sǝkkǝ, kulashi adǝ kessa zauro zau so ro cissǝgǝnyi ro waljin, kuru awowa tuwandin dǝ faltin test dio dǝ ndara son mbeji ro waljinna son.

sourceString: Fourth, because of the descriptive nature of these data, attack rates among persons with and without underlying health conditions could not be compared, and thus the risk difference of severe disease with COVID-19 between these groups could not be estimated.
targetString: Kǝn diyeu mi, sapsawi bayanbe adǝ ikkuwalto bas sǝdin dǝ ro, nǝm ngǝwu wakatǝ kwasabe suro am nǝm dondi laa buroman sandiya zǝkcin mbeji-a ba-a ye dǝ mowonzǝ gǝretimba, kuru adǝgai lan nǝm gade gade fujiwo kwasa COVID-19be ndi kate jam'uwa anyi be dǝ mowonzǝ komtimba wo.

sourceString: Fifth, no conclusions could be drawn about underlying conditions that were not included in the case report form or about different conditions that were reported in a single, umbrella category.
targetString: Kǝn uwu mi, tamoram jili wi ma mowonzǝ kǝla kǝndawa nǝlewabe suro fom rifot kesye ro tǝkkǝnyiyen gotimba au kǝla kǝndawa nǝlewabe do rifotnza suro jam'u falyen tǝdǝna ma soyen.

sourceString: For example, asthma and COPD were included in a chronic lung disease category.
targetString: Misal ro, asǝma-a COPD-a dǝ suro jam'u kwasawa fufube zauro zau be ro tǝkkǝna.

sourceString: Finally, for some underlying health conditions and risk factors, including neurologic disorders, chronic liver disease, being a current smoker, and pregnancy, few severe outcomes were reported; therefore, conclusions cannot be drawn about the risk for severe COVID-19 among persons in these groups.
targetString: Dare dajiram lan, kǝndawa nǝlewabe buroman mbeji-a awowa nǝlewa ro fujiwo sawudin laa soro, suro dǝn mbeji "neurologic disorder"-a, kwasa kǝmattǝnbe zauro zau-a, kǝrmaa ro tafa kǝnza ma ro waltǝ-a, nǝm de gǝnyi-a so ro, tamoramwa zauro zau ganaye rifot tǝdǝ; adǝ nanka dǝ ro, tamoramwa kǝla fujiwo COVID-19 zauro zauyen gotimba dawu am do jam'u anyi lan dasaanabe lan.

sourceString: Persons in the United States with underlying health conditions appear to be at higher risk for more severe COVID-19, consistent with findings from other countries.
targetString: United States lan am do nǝm dondi laa buroman sandiya zǝkcin mbeji sodǝ sandima fujiwo COVID-19 zauro zauye sandiya sǝtayinye suron kasharu wo, awowa lardǝwa gade lan tuwandǝna'a kalkalzǝna.

sourceString: Persons with underlying health conditions who have symptoms of COVID-19, including fever, cough, or shortness of breath, should immediately contact their health care provider.
targetString: Am nǝm dondi laa buroman sandiya zǝkcin mbeji kuru alamawa COVID-19be fanzayin, kange-a, kasau-a au yintǝ ngǝlaro fandǝm gotǝ baa-an kunten so dǝ duwa ro am nǝlewa ro cistaamanza so naazaa.

sourceString: These persons should take steps to protect themselves from COVID-19, through washing their hands; cleaning and disinfecting high-touch surfaces; and social distancing, including staying at home, avoiding crowds, gatherings, and travel, and avoiding contact with persons who are ill.
targetString: Am anyi katapwa kǝlanza COVID-19 ro yitkawobe gozana ma ngǝlawo, mukkonza tulta men; na'a ngǝwu ro letin kadawu ba ro dio-a kuru kuliwa kwasa sawudin yezo-a; kuru am ro cintutǝ-a, faton naptǝ-a, jumla amma-a, samno-a, bǝlaguro-a ro katǝ-an kunten, kuru am dondi ro letǝgǝ ro katǝ-a.

sourceString: Maintaining at least a 30-day supply of medication, a 2-week supply of food and other necessities, and knowledge of COVID-19 symptoms are recommended for those with underlying health conditions.
targetString: Kurunna gananzǝ yaye kau fiyakkǝbe mbeji ro dio-a, karewa kǝmbube-a awowa gade mǝradǝtǝna magǝ indiye mbeji ro dio-a, kuru notǝ alamawa COVID-19be-a samma am nǝm dondi laa buroman sandiya zǝkcin ro tǝkǝra'ana.

sourceString: All persons should take steps to protect themselves from COVID-19 and to protect others.
targetString: Am samma so katapwa kǝlanza COVID-19 ro yitkawobe gozana ma ngǝlawo kuru am gadeye tǝtkayin.

sourceString: All persons who are ill should stay home, except to get medical care; should not go to work; and should stay away from others.
targetString: Am dondi samma so faton napsa, cistǝgǝ liyitabe matǝ ro gǝnyi ma; wande cida ro lezanyi; kuru am gade so ro cintuza.

sourceString: This is especially important for those who work with persons with underlying conditions or who otherwise are at high risk for severe outcomes from COVID-19.
targetString: Adǝ taganasma ro am do am nǝm dondi laa buroman sandiya zǝkcinna au am suro fujiwo nǝm dondi COVID-19be zauye sandiya sǝtayinye lan kasharu'a cidazayin ro zauro faida.

sourceString: Community mitigation strategies, which aim to slow the spread of COVID-19, are important to protect all persons from COVID-19, especially persons with underlying health conditions and other persons at risk for severe COVID-19–associated disease (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/community-mitigation-strategy.pdf).
targetString: Katapwa illa COVID-19be gana ro diobe suro ngurobe, do tartǝgǝ COVID-19ye gana ro sǝdiya sǝraana dǝ, am samma so'a yitkawo ro zauro faida, taganas ma ro am nǝm dondi laa buroman sandiya zǝkcin mbeji ma-a am suro fujiwo COVID-19 zau ye sandiya sǝtayin ye lan kasharu-a (https://www.cdc.gov/coronavirus/2019-ncov/downloads/community-mitigation-strategy.pdf).

sourceString: What is already known about this topic?
targetString: Awi kǝla mau'du adǝyen buroman notǝna wo?

sourceString: Published reports from China and Italy suggest that risk factors for severe COVID-19 disease include underlying health conditions, but data describing underlying health conditions among U.S. COVID-19 patients have not yet been reported.
targetString: Rifotta China-a Italy-a lan baktǝnaye fǝlejin awowa fujiwo nǝm dondi COVID-19be suwudinye suron nǝm dondi buroman kamma zǝkcin ma mbeji, amma sapsawi bayanbe kǝla kǝndawa nǝlewabe buroman mbeji dawu am COVID-19ye sǝtana sǝkkuwaltǝyin dǝ kuwa yaye rifotnzǝ tǝdǝnyi.

sourceString: What is added by this report?
targetString: Awi rifot adǝye sǝra?

sourceString: Based on preliminary U.S. data, persons with underlying health conditions such as diabetes mellitus, chronic lung disease, and cardiovascular disease, appear to be at higher risk for severe COVID-19–associated disease than persons without these conditions.
targetString: Sapsawi bayanbe badiyarambe U.S.be ro wungǝmmiya, am nǝm dondi laa buroman sandiya zǝkcin misallo kwasa shiwur yedei so, kwasa fufube zauro zau so, kuru kwasa karǝgǝ-a letǝ buye-a lezǝna-a, sandima alama suro fujiwo kwasa COVID-19ye sandiya sǝtayinbe lan kasharu, am kwasawa anyi tiyinzan ba'a kozana

sourceString: What are the implications for public health practice?
targetString: Awi so illawa cida nǝlewa jama meuye ro cistaabe ro suwudin dǝ?

sourceString: Strategies to protect all persons and especially those with underlying health conditions, including social distancing and handwashing, should be implemented by all communities and all persons to help slow the spread of COVID-19.
targetString: Fasalla am samma so yitkawo be taganasma ro am nǝm dondi laa buroman sandiya zǝkcin mbeji ma, suro dǝn mbeji kam so ro cintutǝ-a mukko tulta-a, koktǝna ma ngǝla wo ngurowa samma so-a am samma so-a dalil tartǝgǝ COVID-19be banatǝgǝ daptǝ nankaro.

sourceString: Emergence of a Novel Coronavirus (COVID-19): Protocol for Extending Surveillance Used by the Royal College of General Practitioners Research and Surveillance Centre and Public Health England
targetString: Luwo au fǝlangtǝ koronabairos bǝlinye (COVID-19): Ka'idawa Shim Ikko Gǝrtǝgǝbe "Royal College of General Practitioners Research and Surveillance Centre and Public Health England"ye faidatǝna ma.

sourceString: The Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research and Surveillance Centre (RSC) and Public Health England (PHE) have successfully worked together on the surveillance of influenza and other infectious diseases for over 50 years, including three previous pandemics.
targetString: 'Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research and Surveillance Centre (RSC)-a kuru Public Health England (PHE)be-a dǝ rokko kǝla 'influenza'-a kwasawa gade kam ro faltǝyin-a ro shim ikkoyen kǝnasarra ro saa fiwun samin ro cidazana, suro dǝn fǝlangtǝ au wawa yakkǝ burobe mbeji.

sourceString: With the emergence of the international outbreak of the coronavirus infection (COVID-19), a UK national approach to containment has been established to test people suspected of exposure to COVID-19.
targetString: Luwo au fǝlangtǝ kwasa coronavirus (COVID-19) ye d dunya samma ro tartǝgǝnaye dǝn, lardǝ UKbe katap kwasa dǝ'a na fal ro saptǝgǝye gotǝna am COVID-19 ro letaana ro tǝmatǝna ro tes dio men.

sourceString: At the same time and separately, the RCGP RSC's surveillance has been extended to monitor the temporal and geographical distribution of COVID-19 infection in the community as well as assess the effectiveness of the containment strategy.
targetString: Loktu fallan kuru yekkata ro, shim ikko RCGP RSCbe-a dǝ mattǝ samtǝ COVID-19ye suro ngurowabe lan ninitǝgǝ badizǝna kuru adǝgaima fasal tartǝgǝnzǝ daptǝye dǝye faidanzǝ kulasta-a.

sourceString: The aims of this study are to surveil COVID-19 in both asymptomatic populations and ambulatory cases with respiratory infections, ascertain both the rate and pattern of COVID-19 spread, and assess the effectiveness of the containment policy.
targetString: Awowa kǝra adǝye nganzazǝna dǝ shima COVID-19 ro shim ikko suro jumla alama fǝletǝ badizanyi-a kuru kessa fomzayin ma do tiyinzan kwasa yintǝbe mbeji-a, kuru nǝm ngǝwu-a futu COVID-19 tartǝyin notǝ-a, kuru faidatǝ ka'ida daptǝgǝye dǝ kulasta-a.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC, a network of over 500 general practices in England, extract pseudonymized data weekly.
targetString: RCGP RSC dǝ, 'network' 500 samin cidawu nǝlewabe lardǝ Englandye dǝ, magǝ wo son sapsawi bayanbe su kattuwube'a sutuluyin.

sourceString: This extended surveillance comprises of five components: (1) Recording in medical records of anyone suspected to have or who has been exposed to COVID-19.
targetString: Shim ikko gǝrtǝna adǝ awowa uwu suronzǝn dǝga: (1) Suro rekod litaribe lan ndu yaye COVID-19 tiyinzǝn mbeji ro tǝmatǝna au letǝgǝna ro tǝmatǝna rekod ro ikko

sourceString: Computerized medical records suppliers have within a week of request created new codes to support this.
targetString: Am rekod litaribe kompiutaye yioma soye suro magǝ falyen suwa gǝra'ata bǝlin satandǝna adǝ banatǝ ro.

sourceString: (2) Extension of current virological surveillance and testing people with influenza-like illness or lower respiratory tract infections (LRTI)—with the caveat that people suspected to have or who have been exposed to COVID-19 should be referred to the national containment pathway and not seen in primary care.
targetString: (2) Nasha kuli kwasabe ro shim ikko gǝrtǝgǝ-a kuru am nǝm dondi tantanyi'a samunna au nǝm dondi diwal yintǝbe cidiyabe-a ro tes dio--- am do sandi lan COVID-19 mbeji rotǝmatǝna au shiro letana ro tǝmatǝna dǝ diwal daptǝgǝ lardǝbe ro zutǝgǝna ma ngǝla wo ro sumo gǝrta-a kuru wande na nǝlewa ro cistǝgǝ badiyarambe ro sandiya taadǝnyi.

sourceString: (3) Serology sample collection across all age groups.
targetString: (3) Kura ba gana ba ro bu gotǝ tes shiro "Serology" gulzayin dǝ tǝdǝ.

sourceString: This will be an extra blood sample taken from people who are attending their general practice for a scheduled blood test.
targetString: Adǝ am do buro man tes buye ro isana so dǝ ro bu gota gade ro waljin.

sourceString: The 100 general practices currently undertaking annual influenza virology surveillance will be involved in the extended virological and serological surveillance.
targetString: Awowa 100 noata tǝdinma kǝmaa ro shima shim ikko kuli kwasa influenza be saa wo son tǝdin dǝ kǝla ro gozǝna dǝye tǝkkin nasha shim ikko kuli kwasabe-a 'serological'be-a lan.

sourceString: (4) Collecting convalescent serum samples.
targetString: (4) Awo shiro "convalescent serum sample" gulzayin dǝ mowo.

sourceString: We have the opportunity to escalate the data extraction to twice weekly if needed.
targetString: Duluwunde sapsawi bayan tulobe magǝ lan indiro diobe mbeji mǝradǝtǝna maa.

sourceString: Swabs and sera will be analyzed in PHE reference laboratories.
targetString: Awo tes dio be shiro 'swab' sayin dǝ-a 'sera'-a dǝ lab PHE be lan kulastǝ turin.

sourceString: General practice clinical system providers have introduced an emergency new set of clinical codes to support COVID-19 surveillance.
targetString: Am nzundu cida litaribe noatama gǝmtǝgǝma soye lamar COVID-19be ro shim ikko nankaro sandiye fasal ashirbe litarin faidatǝbe yita gatsaana.

sourceString: Additionally, practices participating in current virology surveillance are now taking samples for COVID-19 surveillance from low-risk patients presenting with LRTIs.
targetString: Adǝ ro nzǝra lan, cidawa do lamar kuli kwasabe ro shim ikkobe kǝmaabe ro rǝbtaana so dǝ, kǝmaa dǝ samfǝrwa gozayin COVID-19 nasha am fujiwo gana lan kasharu amma LRTI so mbeji ro shim ikko ro

sourceString: Within the first 2 weeks of setup of this surveillance, we have identified 3 cases: 1 through the new coding system, the other 2 through the extended virology sampling.
targetString: Suro magǝ indi lamar shim ikkobe adǝ koktǝna lan, andeye lamarra au kessa yakkǝ asunyena: Fal dǝ nzundu ashirbe bǝlin dǝ futa men, indi gabsǝna nasha samfǝr kuli kwasabe gotabe gǝrrata me dǝn.

sourceString: We have rapidly converted the established national RCGP RSC influenza surveillance system into one that can test the effectiveness of the COVID-19 containment policy.
targetString: Andeye tini RCGP RSC lardǝbe nzundu tantanyi 'influenzaa' ro shim ikkobe koktǝna ma dǝ'a raksǝ ka'idawa COVID-19 na fallan dapkǝgǝm rotabeye faidanzǝ jarabtǝye ro kalakkaiye.

sourceString: The extended surveillance has already seen the use of new codes with 3 cases reported.
targetString: Shim ikko gǝrtǝgǝna dǝye ba burozǝ faida kalimawa au suwa ashirbe bǝlinye dǝ suruna, kessa 3 bǝlinye rifot tǝdǝna dǝn.

sourceString: Rapid sharing of this protocol should enable scientific critique and shared learning.
targetString: Ka'ida adǝ faidatǝ ngǝwu dǝ kushe tǝ nasha ilmuye yita mowonzǝyin kuru kǝlo ndi kate ammabe ye yita mowonzǝyin.

sourceString: The Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research and Surveillance Centre (RSC) is a network of general practices (GPs) with a nationally representative population that provides pseudonymized data for weekly surveillance of infectious diseases.
targetString: Royal College of General Practitioners (RCGP) Research and Surveillance Centre (RSC) dǝ kǝlkǝlno "network" cidawa noatabe 'general practices(GPs)' ma do jumlanzǝ lardǝbe sha wakkiltǝma do sapsawi bayanbe do su kattuwube'a cin, kwasawa am ro faltǝyin ro shim ikko magǝ magǝn tǝdin dǝ ro.

sourceString: The disease surveillance program is commissioned by Public Health England (PHE) and covers 37 infectious diseases, including influenza.
targetString: Dawarno kwasa ro shim ikkobe dǝ Public Health England (PHE) sha sutuluwu kuru kwasawa kammo faltayin 37 zaksǝ, influenza kunten.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC and PHE have an established collaboration of over 50 years in influenza and respiratory disease surveillance and are now in their 53rd season of surveillance and analysis.
targetString: RCGP RSC -a PHE-a dǝ gawana kǝl saa fiwu ma kozǝna sadǝna nasha kwasa influenza-a kwasawa yintǝbe gade-a ro shim ikkobe lan, kuru kǝmaadǝ ro suro saanza shim ikkobe-a kulashibe-a kǝn 53 fiwun yakkǝn yen kasharu.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC extracts pseudonymized data from a nationally representative sample of over 500 urban and nonurban GPs each week covering a population of over 4 million.
targetString: RCGP RSC dǝ sapsawi bayanbe su kattuwube'a samfǝr wakkiltǝma lardǝbe GPwa 500 ma kozǝna bǝrnibe-a bǝrnibe gǝnyi-a sutuluyin magǝ wo son, jumla am miliyon diyeu ma kozǝnabe adǝgaiyin zakcin.

sourceString: Data from these practices are reported online in a weekly return, which includes monitoring weekly rates of influenza-like illness (ILI) and other communicable and respiratory diseases in England.
targetString: Sapsawi bayanbe cidawa anyibe dǝ 'online' lan rifotnza tǝdin magǝ lan, adǝye suron mbeji magǝ wo son ninitǝgǝ nǝm dondi infuluyenza'a samunzǝna-a kuru kwasawa gade kammo faltǝyin-a yintǝbe-a lardǝ Englandbe lan.

sourceString: We also produce an annual report.
targetString: Andeye kuru rifot saaye tuluwuyen.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC data set includes all coded data and all prescribed items including vaccine exposure.
targetString: Sapsawi bayanbe RCGP RSCye dǝ suronzǝn sapsawi bayanbe ashirtǝna-a kuru karewa gade ruotǝna-a, kalimi gotan kunten.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC conducts virology surveillance each influenza season, with 100 GPs participating in the 2019-2020 season (Figure 1).
targetString: RCGP RSC dǝ zaman tantanyiyewo son kulashi kuli kwasabe dǝ sǝdin, GPwa 100 rǝbtaana suro zamanzǝ din saa 2019-2020.

sourceString: These virology sampling practices are also recruited to be nationally representative (Figure 1).
targetString: Cidawa samfǝr nazaru kuliya ye anyi sandiya allamtǝna lardǝ zam wakkiltǝ ro.

sourceString: GPs take nasopharyngeal swabs from persons showing acute respiratory illness within 7 days of the onset of symptoms.
targetString: GPs so dǝ samfǝr kǝnza men gotin shiro "nasopharyngeal swab" sayin dǝ am nǝm dondi yintǝbe fǝlezayinbe gozayin, suro kau 7 alamawa nǝm dondiye badizǝnayen.

sourceString: Nasopharyngeal swabs are taken from children younger than 5 years showing symptoms of acute bronchitis or bronchiolitis.
targetString: Nasopharyngeal swabs dǝ nduli saa uwun cidiyannin alamawa kwasa 'bronchitis' be au 'bronchiolitis'be fǝlezana ye lan gotin.

sourceString: Additionally, nasopharyngeal samples are taken from anyone 5 years and older showing acute onset of ILI and respiratory synctial virus.
targetString: Adǝ ro nzǝra lan, "nasopharyngeal sample" dǝ na kam saa uwun saminna do alama badiyaram nǝm dondi infuluyenzabe zau ma-a kuru "respiratory synctial virus"-a fǝlezǝnabe lan gotin.

sourceString: Swabs are tested at the PHE Respiratory Virus Unit for influenza to monitor positivity rates and circulating strains, as well as for measuring vaccine effectiveness.
targetString: Awo samfǝr gotabe 'swab" dǝ na shiro "PHE Respiratory Virus Unit for influenza" sayin dǝn tesnza au jarawanza tǝdin, nǝm mbeji kuli kwasabe-a jili kuli kwasabe fomjin ninitǝgǝ ro, kuru faida kalimibe ngaltǝ ro

sourceString: The RCGP RSC successfully conducted a pilot collecting serological samples from adults and linking them to a patient's medical records during the 2018-2019 influenza season.
targetString: RCGP RSC dǝ kǝnasarra ro "serological sample" ammurawabe gozǝ daji rekod litaribe am dondiye'a kǝllono suro zaman infuluyenza saa 2018-2019 ye dǝn.

sourceString: This pilot was in collaboration with the PHE Seroepidemiology Unit and added to the residual blood samples submitted to PHE by National Health Service (NHS) laboratories.
targetString: Cida do jarrabtǝbe shiro "pilot" sayin adǝ ngawana kǝl "PHE Seroepidemiology Unit" be lan cedo kuru samfǝrra buye PHE ro labwa 'National Health Services"ye gǝmzǝgǝna dǝ ro sasarana.

sourceString: Serology can provide important information about background population immunity, and sentinel networks can provide a mechanism for systematic data collection and linkage to medical records and health outcomes.
targetString: Serology ye raksǝ bayan faida-a kǝla kǝmbafi tiyi jumla ammayen cin, kuru daji netwokka hangal gǝnatǝbe soye duluwu sapsawi bayanbe nzundu lan gotabe mbeji ro sadinye kuru rekod wa liyitabe-a tamoramwa nǝlewabe-a kǝlzayin.

sourceString: The serology pilot has demonstrated the ability of the network to collect serology samples in adults.
targetString: Serology pilotye raktǝ netwok dǝye samfǝrwa serologybe ammurawaye na lan mowobe fǝlezǝna.

sourceString: With the COVID-19 outbreak, PHE and RCGP RSC have adapted existing influenza surveillance to monitor the spread of COVID-19 in the community, and this protocol sets out the basis for that collaboration.
targetString: Fǝlangtǝ COVID-19be dǝn, PHE-a RCGP RSC duluwu infuluyenza ro shim ikkobe caman mbeji ma faidata tartǝgǝ COVID-19be suro nguroben ninitǝgǝ nankaro, kuru ka'ida adǝye dalil ngawana kǝl diobe dǝ cina.

sourceString: The primary national strategy for COVID-19 infection is containment, with patients who are at high risk managed via the telephone help system NHS111 and the PHE health protection teams, but the RCGP RSC surveillance is entirely separate.
targetString: Fasal badiyarambe lardǝbe kwasa COVID-19be kǝriutǝbe dǝ shima daptǝgǝ au na fallo sapta, am dondi zauro suro fujiwobe lan dasaana so dǝ lai wayabe NHS111-a kuru 'PHE timnzǝ nǝlewa yitkawobe-aye me dǝn sandi ro cistǝyinna ro, amma RCGP RSC dǝ ruwunzǝ ro kara.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC, by extending its established work, will provide virological and serological surveillance to monitor the temporal and geographical distribution of COVID-19 infection in the community, and assess the effectiveness of the containment strategy.
targetString: RCGP RSC dǝ, cidanzǝ kokkata dǝ grtǝgǝ men, shim ikko "virological-a serological" mbeji ro sǝdin tartǝgǝ kwasa COVID-19be suro nguroyen loktu-a kuru na tartǝyin-a ninita ro, kuru faidatǝ fasal daptǝgǝbe dǝ kulasta nanka ro.

sourceString: We would not be working in isolation on this research.
targetString: Kǝla kulashi adǝyen cida suro ngultǝyen diyemba.

sourceString: We will share the protocol with UK colleagues and the I-MOVE consortium who have recently obtained EU Horizon 2020 funding from the stream “Advancing knowledge for the clinical and public health response to the novel coronavirus epidemic”.
targetString: Andye ka'idawa cidabe anyi rokko sawaande cidabe UKbe-akuru I-MOVE consortium-a faidatiyen, sandi do karungu ro kunguna "EU Horizon 2020 funding"be sowandana dǝ na “Advancing knowledge for the clinical and public health response to the novel coronavirus epidemic” ye lan.

sourceString: It is anticipated that great efficiencies in project management will result through this collaboration than that obtained from countries acting alone.
targetString: Ngawana kǝl adǝ men cida zauro ngǝla tǝmatǝna nasha cida ro cistǝgǝbe lan, lardǝwa ruunza cidazayin so dǝ'a kozǝna.

sourceString: The aim of this study is to identify whether there is undetected community transmission of COVID-19, estimate population susceptibility, and monitor the temporal and geographical distribution of COVID-19 infection in the community.
targetString: Awo kǝra adǝye nganzazǝna dǝ shima tartǝgǝ COVID-19be notǝnyi suro nguroben mbeji la ba ro asutǝ, jumla'a futu kǝske lan au kǝske gǝyi lan kwasaye sǝtayin komtǝ-a, kuru samtǝ loktu-a na kwasa COVID-19be suro nguroben tartǝyin ninita.

sourceString: The objectives of this study are as follows:
targetString: Awowa kǝra adǝye nganzazǝna dǝ sandima.

sourceString: To monitor the burden of suspected COVID-19 activity in the community through primary care surveillance and clinical coding of possible COVID-19 cases referred into the containment pathway
targetString: Kǝrau lamar COVID-19be tǝmatǝna suro nguroyen ninita duluwu shim ikko nǝlewa ro cistǝgǝ badiyarambe men-a kuru su ashirbe litarin kessa COVID-19ye zawal daaptǝgǝye ro zutǝgǝna dǝ ro ikko.

sourceString: To provide virological evidence on the presence and extent of undetected community transmission of COVID-19 and monitor positivity rates among individuals presenting ILI or acute respiratory tract infections to primary care
targetString: Shada nasha 'virology'ye kǝla nǝm mbeji-a kuru nǝm ngǝwu tartǝgǝ COVID-19be suro ngurobe notǝnyi-a kuru dawu am kwasa infuluyenza'a samun tiyinzan mbeji au kwasa zawal yintǝbe tiyinzan mbejiye lan "positive" ro waltǝ ninita kuru sandiya cistǝgǝ badiyarambe ro ikko.

sourceString: To estimate baseline susceptibility to COVID-19 in the community and estimate both symptomatic and asymptomatic exposure rates in the population through seroprevalence monitoring
targetString: Suro nguroben COVID-19ye amma kǝnta komtǝ-a kuru kwasa dǝ ro am letaana do alamawa fǝlezana-a fǝlezanyi-a komtǝ suro ngurobe lan awo shiro 'seroprevalence monitoring' gulzayin dǝ futa men.

sourceString: To pilot implementation of a scheme for collection of convalescent sera with antibody profiles among recovered cases of COVID-19 discharged to the community
targetString: Dawari cida diobe "convalescent sera" mowobe dawu am COVID-19 ye sǝta ngazana ye lan suro ngurobe ro salamtǝna.

sourceString: We intend to capture the following.
targetString: Awowa anyi tawo nyiyanyiye.

sourceString: Clinical workload related to reports of COVID-19 using the codes created to flag cases, those being assessed and where the infection is located are excluded (Figures 2-​-44)
targetString: Kǝrau cidawa litaribe rifotta COVID-19be'a leyatasuwa ashirbe do kessa dǝ nankaro tǝnandǝna dǝ faidatinna ro, sandi kulastǝ tǝdinma-a kuru na kwasa dǝ daana-a dǝ dawun ba,

sourceString: Foreign countries visited in the last 28 days
targetString: Lardǝwa diyabe suro kau 28 kozǝnayen ziyaratǝna ma.

sourceString: Existing codes that may have utility (Tables 1-​-3).3).
targetString: Suwa ashirbe so do waniye faidatin ma (Tewur 1 -- 3).3).

sourceString: Many GPs and primary care teams may not realize that important relevant data can be coded.
targetString: GPs wa-a jamiwa nǝlewa ro cistaabe badiyarambe kada'a sapsawi bayanbe faida'a mowonzǝ su ashirbe tǝkkin ro waniye nozanyi ro waljin.

sourceString: There is also the potential during any pandemic to monitor the effectiveness of any transmission control measures.
targetString: Kuru mowontǝ mbeji suro wawa jili wi yen yaye faidatǝ katapwa faltǝ au tartǝgǝ daptǝye gotǝna dǝ ninitaabe.

sourceString: Reliable coding of letters and test results that will show an infection has become either confirmed or excluded
targetString: Su ashirbe watiya-a tamoramwa tesbe so ro ikkoye fǝlejin kwasa dǝ tawattǝgǝna au ba ro tǝdǝna.

sourceString: The methods will follow the approach used in the current influenza surveillance system and recent serology study, and includes five components: (1) primary care clinical surveillance; (2) virological surveillance; (3) population serological surveillance; (4) convalescent sera in cases; and (5) data curation.
targetString: Duluwuwa dǝ nzundu infuluyenza ro shim ikkoye kǝmaaye dǝ-a kǝra kǝla 'serology' yen karungu ro tǝdǝna dǝ-a zǝgayin, kuru suronzǝn awowa uwu dǝga: (1) shim ikko cistǝgǝ badiyarambe liyitabe; (2) kuli kwasabe ro shim ikko; (3) "serology" jumla amma ye ro shim ikko; (4) sera ngatǝ sǝdin ma suro kessa yen; kuru (5) sapsawi bayanbe na fallo saptǝgǝ.

sourceString: The NHS uses the Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms (SNOMED CT) system of coding, which is normally only updated twice annually.
targetString: NHSdǝ nzundu su ashirbe ikko shiro"Systematized Nomenclature of Medicine Clinical Terms (SNOMED CT) gulzayin dǝ faidatin, shi doni saa wo son indi njong ro bǝlintǝyin ma.

sourceString: There was added complexity as some computerized medical record (CMR) suppliers use the Read coding systems (Read clinical terms version 3 – CTv3), which is no longer updated.
targetString: Nǝm zau tǝrana mbeji saunzǝ dǝ am rekod litaribe kompiutabe gǝmzayindǝ awo shiro "Read coding system" sayin dǝ faidatayin dǝ ro (Read clinical terms version 3 – CTv3), shi doni tǝmma ro bǝlintǝyimba ma.

sourceString: Additionally, there were no clinical codes to record COVID-19 in early February 2020.
targetString: Adǝ ro nzǝra lan, su ashirbe litaribe COVID-19 rekod dio be ba badiyaram kǝntagǝ February be saa 2020be lan.

sourceString: Therefore, the two main GP system suppliers added the five terms shown in Table 4 as system-wide local codes.
targetString: Adǝye sǝkkǝ, am nzundu GP gǝmzayin kura kura indi dǝye awowa uwu Tewur 4 lan fǝletǝna dǝ cashara naptǝ suwa ashirbe fatobe nzundu dǝ sapcinbeyen.

sourceString: A UK emergency release of SNOMED CT concepts for COVID-19 was also subsequently made available across all CMR systems (Table 4).
targetString: Tulo duwasashibe UKye "SNOMED CT concepts"be COVID-19 ye dǝye mbeji ro tǝdǝna nzunduwa CMRbe samma son (Tewur 4).

sourceString: The intention is that these will eventually be mapped to the new SNOMED CT concepts as they become available, allowing recording of relevant data (Multimedia Appendix 1).
targetString: Awo nyiyatǝna dǝ shima sandi anyi samma so waiyya suro ''SNOMED CT concept'' bǝlinbe dǝ ro tǝkkin sa mbeji ro walzaiyya, adǝye kolzǝ sapsawi bayanbe faidajin samma rekod ro tǝkkin (Multimedia Appendix 1).

sourceString: The key requirements for this release were the ability to code (Table 4) a case of COVID-19, exposure to risk of infection (travel to an area where there may be a higher risk), contact with anyone infected with COVID-19, a report that a person had been tested for COVID-19, and that the disease had been excluded (likely a negative test).
targetString: Tulo adǝ nankaro awo mǝradǝtǝna kura dǝ shia nǝm mbeji su ashirbe (Tewur 4) kes COVID-19be ro ikko, fujiwo kwasa gotabe ro gawo (na fujiwo ngǝwu'a ro bǝlagrotǝ), kam laa COVID-19ye sǝtana'a leta, rifot kam laa COVID-19 tiyinzǝn mbeji tesye fǝlezǝnabe so, kuru kwasa dǝ tutuluwuna (misallo tes tiyi lan ba fǝlejin ma).

sourceString: In addition, practices are now able to code any foreign travel undertaken, including the ability to record visits to multiple countries (implemented February 8, 2020).
targetString: Adǝ ro nzǝra lan, cidawa tǝdinye kǝmaa dǝ raksa bǝlaguro lardǝ diyabe ro tǝdǝna jili wi yaye ro su ashirbe sakkin, raktǝ do ziyara lardǝwa kadaro taadǝna be rikod ro ikkon kunten (Kǝntagǝ February e 8, 2020 kokkatǝ).

sourceString: Figures 2-​-44 show the EMIS web implementation.
targetString: Figures 2--44 dǝ "EMIS web implementation" fǝlejin.

sourceString: Currently, virology samples for influenza surveillance are accompanied by a standard request form.
targetString: Kǝrmaa ro, samfǝrra 'virology'be infuluyenza ro shim ikkoye dǝ fom matabe gǝdima sha zǝgayin.

sourceString: For COVID-19, we will create a new request form that will record:
targetString: COVID-19 ro, andeye fom matabe bǝlin tannden shi doni rekod ro sǝkkin:

sourceString: Date of onset of symptoms
targetString: Kau kǝntagǝbe alamawa badizǝna be

sourceString: Diagnosis of any of the following:
targetString: Awowa anyi litarin mbeji gultǝna wa:

sourceString: Acute bronchitis/bronchiolitis in those younger than five years
targetString: Kwasa buronkayetis/buronkiyolayetisbe nduli saa uwun cidiyan ro

sourceString: Lower respiratory tract infection (LRTI)
targetString: Kwasa zawal yintǝbe cidiyabe (LRTI)

sourceString: History of fever (Y/N); measured (Y/N); if yes, level
targetString: Tarihi kangebe (A'aa/A'aa); ngaltǝna wa (Aa'a/A'aa); Aa'a maa, ndawu

sourceString: Shortness of breath (Y/N), if measured: oxygen saturation and respiratory rate
targetString: Yintǝ gana (Aa'a/A'aa), ngaltǝna maa: tuskatǝ oksijinbe-a nǝm ngǝwu yintǝbe-a

sourceString: Recent travel (Y/N); if yes, countries visited in last 14 days
targetString: Karugu ro bǝlaguro (Aa'a/A'aa); Aa'a maa, lardǝwa suro kau 14 kozǝnayen ziyaratǝna

sourceString: Contact with a named person with confirmed COVID-19 (Y/N) with a free text comment about the level of certainty
targetString: Kam laa su-a COVID-19'a ro tawattǝgǝna ro letǝgǝ (Aa'a/A'aa) bayan kǝla daraja tawadǝbe'a ro.

sourceString: These codes will be grouped ontologically into “definite”, “probable”, “possible”, and “not a case” using our standard approach to grouping codes (Table 5), which has been used previously across disease areas.
targetString: Suwa ashirbe anyi jam'u ro tǝkkin "tawadǝ", "waniye", "mowonjin", kuru "kes gǝnyi" nzundunde gǝdima su ahirbe jam'u ro ikkobe faidatiyenna ro (Tewur 5), shi doni buron na'a kwasa'a lan faidatǝa ma.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC definition for ILI is shown in Multimedia Appendix 2.
targetString: RCGP RSC ye ma'ananzǝ ILI be dǝ suro Multimedia Appendix 2be lan fǝletǝna.

sourceString: Public Presentation of Data Using an Observatory and Dashboards
targetString: Sapsawi bayanbe jama meu ro na wutin "observatory-a dashboard-a" lan yita gattǝgǝ

sourceString: We will develop an observatory to present data nationally and a dashboard for feedback to practices about their data quality and collection of virology and serology samples.
targetString: Andeye na wutabe sapsawi bayabe lardv samma so ro yita gattǝgǝbe tanden kuru 'dashboard' jawawu kǝla nǝm ngǝla sapsawi bayanbe-a kuru samfǝrra 'virology'be-a 'serology'be-a mowobe kǝlan.

sourceString: This is based on coding described in Table 4.
targetString: Adǝ su ashirbei kko suro Tewur 4 ye lan tukkuwaltǝgǝna dǝro wungatǝgǝ.

sourceString: Definite case will be presented on our dashboard as “cases” of COVID-19.
targetString: Kes tawadǝ-a 'dashboard' nde lan fǝlein "kessa" COVID-19be ro.

sourceString: Possible cases will be presented as “Under investigation” (investigating).
targetString: Kessa mowonjin dǝ naptǝ "Cidiya kulashi yen" ro fǝletin (kulastin)

sourceString: “Not a case” will be presented as “Excluded”.
targetString: Kes gǝnyi dǝ "tutuluwuna" ro fǝletin.

sourceString: Online data has been established within the initial few weeks in the COVID-19 Observatory (Figure 5), indicating the overall number of patients and rate per 10,000 patients of cases confirmed or under investigation, as well as where the virus is excluded.
targetString: Sapsawi bayanbe 'Online' tutuluwuna suro magǝwa gana badiyarambeye lan na COVID-19 kurube lan (Figure 5), adadu am dondiye samma-a kuru nǝm ngǝwu kessa awatǝna ye suro kes 10,000 au cidiya kulashiyen, kuru na kuli kwasabe dǝ ba ro tawattǝgǝna'a.

sourceString: We have the option to move to twice weekly surveillance reports with a scope to change this to daily reporting.
targetString: Karnonde magǝ lan indi ro rifot shim ikkobe ro kotǝbe mbeji, hangal nde wajiya wo son rifot dio ro iyyenna ro.

sourceString: We will continue virology sampling from our sentinel practices, rather than discontinuing as seasonal influenza declines.
targetString: Samfǝr dio "virology"be dǝ gonye koyen, susu wanǝm koltǝbe ro zaman inuluyenzabe kojiya.

sourceString: Additionally, we will recruit more surveillance practices.
targetString: Adǝ ro nzǝra lan, cidawa shim ikkobe gade soye gonyen.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC virology practices will aim to undertake 200-300 nasopharyngeal swabs per week across the RCGP RSC sentinel network, collecting specimens across all age bands.
targetString: RCGP RSCye cidawanzǝ "virology"be dǝ magǝ wo son" nasopharyngeal swabs" 200-300 sǝdiya sǝraa ewok RCGP RSC samma son, "specimen"wa na kura ba gana bayen tumoyin.

sourceString: In addition to the inclusion criteria for influenza virology surveillance (ILI, acute bronchitis/bronchiolitis), participating practices will take nasopharyngeal swab samples from any people showing acute symptoms of LRTI if the onset of symptoms is within 7 days.
targetString: Awowa do shim ikko 'virology' infuluyenzabe ro kwasa'a (ILI, buronkayetis/buronkiyolayetis zauro zau) sǝkkin ro kǝltǝgǝ lan, cidawa do tǝdinye dau ro tǝkkin samfǝr "nasopharyngeal swab"ye na ndu yaye alamawa LRTIbe fǝlejin yen badiyaram alamawabe dǝ kau 7 kozǝnyi maa.

sourceString: RCGP RSC research officers and practice liaison staff will manage practices to achieve a total national sample of 200-300 swabs per week.
targetString: RCGP RSC ye cidawunzǝ kulashi diobe-a cidawu "practice liaison staff" sayin dǝ'a ye cidawa ro cissayin lardǝ samma son kǝnasar samfǝr 200-300 magǝ wo son gotabe fando ro.

sourceString: This could be increased if PHE modelers require more samples.
targetString: Adǝye mowonzǝ tǝrayin cidawu PHEbe samfǝr ngǝwu mazaiyya.

sourceString: Samples from each practice would be spread across the following age groups: < 5 years, 5-17 years, 18-64 years, and 65 years and older
targetString: Samfǝrwa cida wo soye dǝ jam'uwa ngǝlibe anyi ro tartǝyin: saa < 5, saa 5-17, saa 18-64, kuru saa 65-a adǝ ro kura wo-a.

sourceString: Samples (swabs or serum) collected will be sent via prepaid envelopes addressed to the appropriate PHE laboratory for analysis.
targetString: Samfǝrra (swab au serum) tǝmona dǝ lab PHEbe sandǝna ro embulop men zutǝyin.

sourceString: All samples collected will be tested for the presence of influenza and COVID-19.
targetString: Samfǝrra tǝmona samma so infuluyenza-a COVID-19-a ro jarabtin au tes tǝdin.

sourceString: Additionally, PHE will retrospectively test any influenza virology samples collected between early and mid-February 2020 for COVID-19.
targetString: Adǝ ro nzǝra lan, PHEye samfǝrra 'virology' infuluyenzabe jili wi yaye ndi kate badiyaram februaryyen sǝta dawunzǝ ro kude saa 2020yen tǝmona ro tes COVID-19ye sǝdin.

sourceString: Practices will still follow the PHE protocol for COVID-19 with respect to people at risk of infection who should be signposted down the containment pathway, rather than physically attend their practice.
targetString: Cidawa dǝ ka'idawa PHEbe COVID-19be dǝ zǝgayin nasha am suro fujiwo sandiya kwasaye kǝntabe lan kasharu sandi do sandiya zawal kwasa dǝ daptǝgǝye ro tǝkkǝna ma ngǝla wo ma, ngai cidawanza dioye susu dǝ ro.

sourceString: Direct testing of those who attend surgery remains permitted, but we have also rolled out self-swabbing at home.
targetString: Tes dio am tiyata ro rǝbtaana ye dǝ kasatkata ro kara, amma swab kǝlaro dio tuluyena.

sourceString: Summary of processes are detailed in Multimedia Appendix 3.
targetString: Kasartǝ duluwuwa ye dǝ Multimedia Appendix 3 lan bayantǝna.

sourceString: Everyone with an ILI or a respiratory illness who contacts a GP (eg, phones for an appointment) should be asked specifically about recent travel to China and other countries flagged in current PHE advice, or if they have had contact with other people with COVID-19.
targetString: Ndu yaye kam nǝm dondi infuluyenza-a samun shi lan mbeji au nǝm dondi yintǝbe shi lan mbeji kuru GP ro letǝgǝna (misallo waya loktu gǝnatǝ nankaro) sandiya tuworǝ taganas ro kǝla bǝlaguro China-a lardǝwa gade so-a yen, au am COVID-19-a ro letaana la letaanyi ro.

sourceString: If these screening enquiries are positive, the patient would be advised to not come to the practice but instead to follow the PHE flow sheet.
targetString: Awowa sǝkǝrinin lan kulastǝna dǝ tawadǝ au mbeji ro wallono maa, kam dondi dǝ ro shawari tin wande isǝnyi ro kuru susu dǝ ro "PHE flow sheet" dǝ zǝ'a.

sourceString: This can be by a reception or clinician staff, depending on individual practice protocol.
targetString: Adǝye cidama litaribe men yaye mowonjin, ka'idawa cidabe ngǝmye lan Kara.

sourceString: These calls should be coded into the GP CMR system and can be reported as part of the RCGP RSC weekly return.
targetString: Bowotǝwa anyi suro nzundu GP CMR suwa ashirbe ro tǝkkin kuru mowonzǝ rifotnzǝ tǝdin naptǝ RCGP RSCbe magǝ wo son kalaktǝyin ma.

sourceString: We have developed training material to support this coding (Multimedia Appendix 4).
targetString: Karewa allamtǝye tandena lamar su ashirbe ikkoye dǝ banata ro (Multimedia Appendix 4).

sourceString: These include prompt cards for:
targetString: Adǝye su ron mbeji kati wa:

sourceString: Practice reception or triage staff: for coding of any patients calling the practice with symptoms of acute respiratory infection with a history of travel to important areas based on PHE advice
targetString: Cida mowo au cidawu triagebe: su ashirbe ikko kam dondi cida dǝ'a nǝm dondi nasha yintǝbe nankaro bowojin shi doni tarihi bǝlaguro na'a PHE ye faida'a gulzǝna ro sǝdǝna.

sourceString: Administrative staff or clinicians who code: to encourage consistent coding of results for any suspected cases, including coding of negative results for exclusion
targetString: Cidawu cidaram notobe-a cidawu litaribe -a do su ashirbe sakkin: tamoramwa kes tǝmatǝna jili wi yaye ro su ashirbe ikko, tamoramwa kwasa ba guljinye ro su ashirbe ikko kunten.

sourceString: Practices participating in virology surveillance will opportunistically collect blood samples from patients coming into the practice for a routine blood test.
targetString: Cidawa do shim ikko 'virology ' yen sandi mbeji dǝ daata ro samfǝr bu'ye na am dondi tes bu'ye ngai dio ro isana yen gozayin.

sourceString: Patients who attend their practice for a routine blood test will be asked to provide an additional sample for serology.
targetString: Am dondi do jarawa bu'ye ngai ro isana dǝ sandiya tuworǝ bu gade jarawa "serology" ye nanzan gotin.

sourceString: We have conducted initial searches within the RCGP RSC database to look at the number of full blood count (FBC) results and overall rates in adults and children (Figures 6-​-9).9).
targetString: Andeye kulashi buroye diyena suro na RCGP RSC sapsawi bayanbe sapcin dǝn, adadu tamoramwa "full blood count (FBC)"ye kuru nankaro kuru nǝm ngǝwu dawu ammurawa-a nduli-ayen (Figures 6--9).9).

sourceString: An FBC is one of the most common tests performed, and we hope this will give an approximate indication of overall numbers of blood tests performed.
targetString: FBC dǝ shi tes zauro ngǝwu ro tǝdin soye falnza, kuru tǝmanyena adǝye tessa buye tǝdin samma soye adadu cin ro.

sourceString: The sampling rate, per 100,000 patients was highest for children 15-17 years of age and 60 year or older in adults, with the lowest rates in children 0-4 years of age and 18-29 years of age in adults (Figures 6-​-99).
targetString: Adadu am ngaltǝna ye dǝ, suro am dondi 100,000 ye dǝ duli ma zauro nguwu wo ngǝli 15-17 kuru ngǝli 60 aw samin rashidiwa lan, adadu zauro gana duli lan ngǝli 0-4 kuru ngǝli 18-29 suro rashidiwa yen (Figures 6--99).

sourceString: We will provide 1000 serology baseline samples across all ages that reflect the varying rates of attendance by age.
targetString: Bu rizabtǝ 1000 kǝla ngǝli samma so yen yiyen shi dǝwo adadu ngǝliye wo fǝlejin ma.

sourceString: Additionally, we will test if we can obtain these all from virology practices to enhance the yield.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, ande ye rizabnye ruyen awowa adǝ samma so ilmu kǝla kwasa kulastaye dǝn fandiyen wa ro kuru fando dǝga ngalautǝ ro.

sourceString: A good geographical spread is important, so PHE can advise on areas where serology will most usefully be collected.
targetString: Na kura kornǝm gotǝ dǝ zauro faida, adǝ nankaro PHE ye raksǝ shawari cin kǝla ndara bu ngalte dǝ tǝdiya sandǝna wo yen

sourceString: This will be followed by 800 samples monthly.
targetString: Ngawo adǝyen kǝntawu wo son bu gotǝ 800 ngawo dǝ zǝayin.

sourceString: The sample will be stratified with 200 specimens for prepandemic survey (100 for monthly) in the following age groups: < 5 years, 5-17 years, 18-64 years, and 65 years or older.
targetString: Bu gotǝna dǝ sha kashi 200 yaktin kulashi kawu kwasa dǝ ye ro (100 kǝntawu wo so ye) futu kashi nglibe adǝ yeyi ro: < 5 saa, 5-17 saa, 18-64 saa, kuru saa 65 aw samin.

sourceString: The younger patients, in many practices younger than 14 years, and in nearly all for children younger than 8 years will require pediatric serology surveillance.
targetString: Duliwa dondi sǝnana so dǝ, awo nguwu so ro tǝdin dǝ saa 14 ro ganawo dǝn, kuru samma so karǝngeya duli saa 8 ro gana wo dǝn kulashi bu gotǝye duli sǝnanaram ye mǝradǝzain.

sourceString: We will develop a new request form for practices to capture recent travel and exposure to COVID-19.
targetString: Ande ye fom bǝlin korobe tanden kǝndo ro bǝlaro karǝngǝ ye-a COVID-19 ro letǝgǝ-a fǝlejin ma.

sourceString: We will pilot a scheme for collecting convalescent serology from people with confirmed cases and who have had an acute virology sample at the time of their infection.
targetString: Ande ye fasal la bu am kwasa dǝn ngazana ye ngaltǝ badinyiyen kǝla am kwasa dǝ tawatkata yen-a kuru am dǝwo zauro bunzan kuli kwasabe mbeji ro fǝlezǝna so dǝn sa sandiya zamtǝna dǝn.

sourceString: This is to identify a carrier state in patients who have recovered from the virus but may continue shedding the virus.
targetString: Adǝ ye hal kam kuli kwasabe dǝn ngazǝna dǝwo waneye kwamison kuli kwasabe dǝ tarzayin ye dǝ notǝ ro.

sourceString: If there are a small number of cases, this may assist in developing a test kit for patients to take to their own GP and explore its acceptability to patients.
targetString: Adadu kwasa dǝ ye dǝ gana ma, adǝ banazǝ awo ngaltǝye dǝ amnza dondi dǝ ro satandin goza GP nza ro sadin kuru futu am dondi dǝ ye suwondai dǝ asuzain.

sourceString: If there are a large number of COVID-19 cases nationally, convalescent samples could be collected from RCGP RSC practices where there are confirmed cases, with the ability to link to the full medical record.
targetString: Adadu am COVID-19 ye zamzǝna dǝ lardǝ dǝ samman nguwu ro waljiya, bu am ngazana ye dǝ gotin RCGP RSC kǝndo lan na dǝwo kwasa dǝ mbeji ro tawatkata dǝn, raktǝ kakkadǝ litaribe ro kamil ro kǝltǝyin men.

sourceString: This process may include checking pseudonymized NHS numbers for positive individuals at RCGP RSC practices, checking current PHE guidance regarding considerations of infectiousness for confirmed cases, and offering the patient an appointment following the previously mentioned process.
targetString: Zawal adǝ ye suro dǝn kulashi lamba NHS ye gǝrata ye am tiyinzan mbeji ma ye na RCGP RSC kǝndo yen mbeji, Kulashi kashimo PHE ye kǝrmaye kǝla nǝm tartra kwasa tawatkata ye, kuru kam dondi dǝga dotǝ-a ngawo zawal manatǝna dǝ yen.

sourceString: This needs to be carefully coordinated nationally across the network and may require PHE to ensure individuals are not contacted by multiple agencies.
targetString: Adǝ ye mǝradǝ karaskata ro kǝlakǝl yoye lardǝ samma so ye mbeji kate kate gawilwu samma so yen kuru PHE ye mǝradǝ am so dǝ cidawu kada ye sandiro manazanyi ro tawattǝ ye mbeji.

sourceString: RCGP RSC could provide a useful structure to channel the initial contact once PHE has made a request.
targetString: RCGP RSC ye fasal la faida suwudin kam buron matǝgǝna dǝga zutuye tinyi sa PHE ye majiya.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC practices participating in the annual influenza virology surveillance have started sampling from patients showing symptoms of a LRTI.
targetString: RCGP RSC kǝndo dǝ suro nazaru saa saa ye kǝla tantayi yen sadin mbeji ma dǝ bu am dǝwo alamawa LRTI ye fǝlezǝna ye gotǝ badizana.

sourceString: All samples received are being tested for influenza and COVID-19.
targetString: Bu dǝwo tǝmona dǝ samma kange tantayi-a COVID-19-a mbeji la ba ro kulaskatǝ.

sourceString: The RCGP RSC will explore ways to collect convalescent samples from any patients tested positive for COVID-19 through the extension of the virological surveillance.
targetString: RCGP RSC dǝ ye zawalwa bu am kwasa COVID-19 yin ngazǝna ye gotǝye wujin zawal kulashi kela kuli kwasabe dǝ farakǝgǝ men.

sourceString: From the start, we will be carefully curating data to ensure that it can be used for future studies.
targetString: Badiyaram dǝn, ande ye bayanna samnyen nazaru fuye dǝn faidatin ro tawattǝgǝ ro.

sourceString: Our clinical data will be linked to virology.
targetString: Bayannande litariye dǝ kulashi kwasabe dǝ ro kǝltǝyin.

sourceString: We will curate our data using the Findable, Accessible, Interoperable, Reusable principles.
targetString: Bayanna samnyen kaidawa ndetuwondin ma, Fando butuwa ma, Nduso ye raksǝ faidatin ma, Waltǝm rangnǝm faidatǝmin ma dǝn faidatǝyen.

sourceString: To facilitate this our data set is listed with Health Data Research UK and the European Health Data Evidence Network.
targetString: Bayannande adǝga banatǝ ro bayanna kulashi nǝlefayey UK-a kuru European Health Data Evidence Network-a yen isabtǝna.

sourceString: The statistical methodology is in support of a policy approach to widespread disease outbreak, where so-called nonpharmaceutical interventions (NPIs) are used to respond to an emerging pandemic to produce disease suppression.
targetString: nzundu isau men sursur kǝngaye dǝ kaida kwasa nguwu ro tartǝgǝyin dǝga kaltǝge ye dǝga jirezǝgǝna, na dǝwo awo bana kurunye gǝnyi (NPIs) ma lan faidatǝ kwasa tartǝgǝyin ma dǝ kaltǝgǝ ro awo kwasa ratsǝyin ma tǝnandǝna.

sourceString: This policy aims to reduce contact rates in the population and thereby reduce transmission of the virus.
targetString: Kaida adǝ awo nganzazǝna dǝ shima suro jama ye dǝn adadu kam ro letǝgǝye dǝ fulutu ro adǝye sǝkǝ kuli kwasabe dǝ tartǝgǝ dǝ fulutin.

sourceString: To implement this the UK government has recently articulated the desire to implement population self-isolation measures.
targetString: Awo adǝga tawattǝgǝ ro gomnati UK ye dǝ ye nyanzǝ kataabwa jamaye kǝlanzala men kǝlanza kortǝye dǝ bayanzǝna.

sourceString: By targeting the reproduction number (R) (the average number of secondary cases each case generates) and aiming to reduce the R to below 1, the policy seeks to reduce case numbers to low levels or (as seen in previous outbreaks with severe acute respiratory syndrome and Ebola) to eliminate human-to-human transmission.
targetString: Adadu yamboye au fafanǝm nguwutǝye (R) dǝ nganzatǝ men (adadu dǝwo dawu dawu ye ma kwasa kǝn ndimi ye dǝwo kwasa bi so sambin ma dǝ) kuru nyanzǝ R dǝga fulunǝm 1 yin cidaan ro kudoye, kaida dǝ kasadǝnzǝ adadu kwasabe dǝ cidâ ro saam ganatǝgl ye mbeji aw (futu ngawon kǝla falangtǝ kwasa yintǝye -a Ebola-a yi turuna dǝyeyi) kate kate adamngana yen tartǝgǝ dǝ ba ro diwo ro.

sourceString: As the experience from the 2009 H1N1 pandemic has shown, NPIs can be a crucial component of pandemic mitigation.
targetString: Futu kwasa dinaye H1N1 2009 ye dǝ ye fǝlezǝna dǝ yeyi, NPIs dǝ raksǝ awo dǝwo faida fal kwasa dinabe adǝga kǝriwtǝye ro waljin.

sourceString: Key to the focus of our study will be the estimation of peak cases in the population and continual monitoring by data collection and modelling the potential growth and emergence of subsequent peaks in new cases as social distancing measures are relaxed.
targetString: Nazaru nde dǝ ye na hangal cin dǝ shima adadu kwasa dǝ ye zauro nguwu ro zuwana ma suro jamaye dǝ tǝadirtǝgǝ kuru datǝ ba ro Sursuri kǝnga-a bayanwa sabtǝ men kuru futu tǝraiya waljin ro kuru so kuru ngawo dǝn adadu zauro nguwu ro kǝmba bǝlin ro kwasa dǝ waatǝ so sa katabwa am so ro fattǝgǝ ba ye dǝ kabaitǝgǝya.

sourceString: There has already been publication of important disease epidemiological measures concerning the outbreak of COVID-19 in mainland China.
targetString: Kerma ro ruwo lǝbtǝna mbeji kǝla nazaru kwasa kura ye katabwanzǝ gotin so yen kǝla falangtǝ COVID-19 ye suro lardǝ China yen.

sourceString: A further fundamental measure in pandemic dynamics is the length of time from infection to when a person is infectious to others and the mean duration of infectiousness.
targetString: Katab gade zauro faida suro kwasa dina ye dǝ ye fafaltǝnzǝ dǝ shima loktu dǝwo gojin ma dǝ sa zamtǝye dǝn tai sa kam dǝ ye am gade ro tarzǝyin ro waljin ro kude.

sourceString: These factors, if estimated accurately, will give good predictions for the likely length of the pandemic, the final number of infected cases.
targetString: Awowa adǝ, kalkal ro isabtǝna ro waljiya, loktu kwasa dǝ ye gojin ro tǝmata kalkal ro cin, adadu datelaye am kwasa dǝ ye zamzǝna ye-a.

sourceString: We intend to apply approximate Bayesian inference (ABC) to (possibly spatially heterogeneous) Susceptible-Exposed- Infectious-Removed (SEIR) stochastic epidemic models.
targetString: Ande ye nyaye approximate Bayesian inference (ABC) to (possibly spatially heterogeneous) Susceptible-Exposed- Infectious-Removed (SEIR) stochastic epidemic models so dǝn faidatǝ ro.

sourceString: Such techniques are highly parallelizable and have been successfully applied to many fields including disease transmission modelling.
targetString: Nzunduwa jili adǝ zaumaro raktǝ kǝlatilowa ro rataltǝyin kuru man fellawa gade son faidatǝ kǝnasar turuna surodǝn nzudu dǝwo kwasa tartǝgǝ ngaltǝye ye mbeji.

sourceString: They are particularly suited to situations where likelihood functions are absent and where more traditional approaches such as Markov chain Monte Carlo are impractical.
targetString: Sandi adǝ musamman ma ro halla sa awo fuwun wajin so dǝ raktǝ tǝmatinmba ro waljiya kuru loktu zawalwa kureye ada alama Markov chain Monte Carlo so dǝ muwonzǝ faidatinmba ro waljiya.

sourceString: Such an approach has been demonstrated to work effectively on the ASPREN surveillance data, a network of sentinel GPs and nurse practitioners who report deidentified information on ILIs and other conditions, where issues such as missing data and the need to model the observation process itself has been successfully addressed.
targetString: Katab adǝ fǝlezǝna ngǝlaro cidajin ro kǝla ASPREN surveillance data, fasal la sentinel GPs ye kuru cidawu liyitariye dǝwo hawar kǝlanzǝ asutunyi ma kǝla ILIs-a halla gade-a yen sadin ma do-a, na dǝwo lamarwa bayanna fatsǝna ye-a mǝradǝ nzundu sursuri kǝngaye dǝga Waltǝm sasǝrtǝye dǝga ngǝla ro manatǝna dǝn.

sourceString: Furthermore, peaks in new cases have been estimated by distributional methods.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, kwasawa bǝlin ye adadunzǝ zauro nguwu ma tǝadir nzǝ dǝ nzundu shiro distributional gultin dǝ men isabtin.

sourceString: Estimates of the parameters of the SEIR model are tractable on large data sets because of parallelizability, and these methods have been implemented in several R libraries; we intend to use the libraries ABSEIR (deposited on GitHub: https://tinyurl.com/vqu35cj) and abctools (https://tinyurl.com/tfjavz4) to estimate epidemic measures on a weekly basis.
targetString: Tǝadir nangam SEIR model ye dǝ faidatǝ butuwa kǝla bayanna nguwu yen sawo raktǝ samǝntǝyin nankaro, are tractable on large data sets because of parallelizability, kuru nzunduwa adǝ kǝla ku njim kǝraye R ye kadan faidatǝna; njimwa kǝraye adǝn faidatǝ ro nyanyena ABSEIR (deposited on GitHub: https://tinyurl.com/vqu35cj) and abctools (https://tinyurl.com/tfjavz4) katabwa kwasa dinaye mawu mawu lan tǝadir tǝro.

sourceString: Since we are fitting an SIR-epidemic model in the ABC routine, we anticipate that our results will be robust against weekly case data containing relatively small counts.
targetString: Fasal SIR-epidemic model ye kǝltabe suro letǝgǝram ABC ye ro yikiyen dǝga. Tǝmanyena natijande dǝ zauro ngǝla ro waljin kǝla bayanna mawu mawu ye kǝla kwasa ye dǝn shi dǝwo ne suronzǝn adadu gana ma ye dǝn.

sourceString: For example, see for the ABC methodology applied to the Tristan da Cunha common cold data from 1967, where counts of I (number of infectious cases) and R (number of recovered cases) are in the tens at most.
targetString: Misallo, wune nzudu BBC ye dǝ kǝla applied to the Tristan da Cunha yen kǝla bayanna tantayi yen sa 1967 faidatǝna, ma dǝwo isawu where counts of I ye dǝ (adadu kwasawa tartǝgǝyin ye) kuru R (adadu am ngazana ye) so dǝ nguwu so ro Kate kate meu yen.

sourceString: Finally, in addition to the above methodology we will employ the Kaplan-Meier method with two outcomes (death and recovery) to estimate the case fatality ratio.
targetString: Dare dajilamen, nzundu samiye dǝn nguron ro nzundu, nzundu Kaplan-Meier dǝn faidatǝyen natija indiya (kǝrmu-a ngatǝ-) kǝrmu kwasa dǝ ye dǝ tǝadirtǝgǝ ro.

sourceString: This approach is independent of the ABC methodology and will allow comparisons between estimates from the two modelling approaches to judge robustness of results.
targetString: Zawal adǝ nzundu ABC ye dǝro letǝnyi kui man kolzǝ kate kate zawalwa ndi ye rataltǝyin nǝm ngalaw natija dǝn wuwom kamtǝ ro.

sourceString: RCGP RSC's surveillance with PHE is defined as Health Protection under Regulation 3 of The Health Service (Control of Patient Information) Regulations 2002.
targetString: Sursuri kǝnga RCGP RSC's ye dǝ rokko PHE ye dǝn dǝ sha nzǝrifo nǝlefa yen buwotin sidiya wuwom kǝn ǝ mi cida nǝlefa ye dǝn (bayan kam dondi ye yitkaw) Wuwom2002 ye.

sourceString: This has been confirmed by PHE's Caldicott Guardian's Office.
targetString: Adǝ ye cidaram PHE ye PHE's Caldicott Guardian's ye dǝ ye tawatsǝna.

sourceString: We do not see any increased risk to practices or practitioners taking part in this surveillance.
targetString: Ande ye tajirwafi ma tǝrana kǝla cida-a cidawu-a yen suro sursuri kǝngaye adǝ lan ruyende.

sourceString: Infection prevention and control advice will follow extant national guidance.
targetString: Shawari kwasa faitǝ-a katǝ-a ye dǝ kashimo lardǝ ye kure ye dǝ zǝayin.

sourceString: Any cases identified will be managed according to the PHE/NHS guidance in force at the time, including advice for identified contacts.
targetString: Kwasa asutǝna wo so futu kashimo PHE/NHS ye ro cistuwuyin shi dǝwo loktu dǝn cidatin ma dǝ, suro dǝn shawari am dǝwo Asutǝna ye-a son.

sourceString: However, our training will include reminders about safe handling of specimens and revision of infection control measures anticipated to be high in our practices.
targetString: Adǝyeyi ma, darasǝ nde dǝ suro dǝn taktǝgǝ kǝla futu nzǝrifowa ro bu gotǝna dǝga rota-a tawtaw kǝnga-a kǝla katabwa kwasa tartǝgǝ kaltǝge ye-a tǝmatǝna cida nde dǝn nguwu ro waljin ro.

sourceString: It is a key part of Regulation 12 about safe care and treatment, periodically inspected by the Care Quality Commission.
targetString: Shidǝ huwom 12 ye kǝla cistuwu nǝlefa ye-a kurun diwo-a yen, kǝla kǝlan cidaram nǝm ngalaw ro cistuwu ye Care ye dǝ ye kulashhin.

sourceString: Travel History and Clinical Descriptors of the COVID-19 Infections
targetString: Bayan bǝlaro ye-a siffawa liyitariye-a tartǝgǝ COVID-19 ye

sourceString: The RCGP RSC practices have been advised on the clinical coding that has been made available for COVID-19 across all CMR systems.
targetString: Cidawa RCGP RSC ye dǝ shawari tina kǝla fasal liyitariye dǝwo COVID-19 ye dǝro fasalla CMR ye dukso ro.

sourceString: This includes information on coding of clinical descriptors (Table 4) and any recent travel history.
targetString: Adǝ ye suronzǝ dǝn bayan kǝla bayanna gǝrata liyitariye (Table 4)-a kuru bǝlaro la karǝngǝn tǝdǝnaye-a.

sourceString: Establishment of Extended Virology Sampling
targetString: Kulashi kǝla kuli kwasaben kuratǝgǝna ma koktǝ

sourceString: The RCGP RSC practices participating in the annual influenza virology surveillance have started sampling from patients showing symptoms of LRTI.
targetString: Cidawa RCGP RSC ye dǝwo kulashi kuli kwasabe kǝla tantayi yen saa saa lan tǝdin ma dǝro rǝbtana ma dǝ ye bu gotǝ badizana ba am dǝwo alamawa LRTI ye fǝlezana so yen.

sourceString: All samples received are being tested for influenza and COVID-19.
targetString: Bu dǝwo tǝmona dǝ samma kange tantayi-a COVID-19-a mbeji la ba ro kulaskatǝ.

sourceString: This has led to initial early identification of background spread in low-risk patients.
targetString: Adǝ ye cidaamen tartǝgǝ kam dondi kambayi ye sǝkǝ daten Asutǝna.

sourceString: As of March 7, 2020, the surveillance system has detected 2 cases of COVID-19 in low-risk patients with no history of travel through extended virological sampling.
